Tripiá¹­aka Master from the Western Regions, Chao Feng Da Fu Shi Hong Lu Qing
Dharma-transmitting Great Master Shi Hu, Translated by Imperial Decree
Thus have I heard:
Once, the Buddha was in the village of Kuru, together with a community of monks.
At that time, Venerable Ä€nanda was alone in a place, and in the middle of the night, he had this thought:
The meaning of the dharmas arisen from conditions is very profound and difficult to understand. Only the World-Honored Buddha, who possesses right and universal knowledge, is able to expound it well.
Having had this thought, in the morning he left his place and came to where the Buddha was.
Having arrived where the Buddha was, he bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, extended his greetings, and then withdrew to stand to one side. He then said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

I was alone in a place, and in the middle of the night, I had this thought: The dharmas arisen from conditions are very profound and difficult to understand. I wish that the World-Honored Buddha would expound it for me.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Ä€nanda:
It is so, it is so.

The principle of dependent origination is profound and subtle, difficult to see, difficult to understand, and difficult to contemplate. Only the noble ones with skillful wisdom can discern it, not the ignorant.
Why is it so?
Ignorant beings, in this world and the next, cease and are reborn again, thus cycling in this way, all because of not understanding the principle of dependent origination.
Ä€nanda!
You should know that all phenomena arise from causes and conditions, one after another, and therefore the cycle of birth and death cannot be severed.
The principle of dependent origination refers to old age and death, which occur due to birth as a condition;
if the principle of birth did not exist, how could old age and death exist?
Thus, birth is a condition for the cycle of birth and death to continue.

Namely, due to the conditions of aquatic beings, aquatic beings are born; due to the conditions of flying birds, flying birds are born; due to the conditions of various species, various species are born; up to due to the conditions of human beings, human beings are born. For this reason, various beings are born from mutual conditions.
Ä€nanda!
Know that this law of birth is a false and impermanent law. This accumulation, this cause, and this condition give rise to old age and death. Therefore, old age and death are also impermanent.
Furthermore, what is the condition for the law of birth?
Namely, the law of existence is the condition.
Because of existence, the law of birth arises;
if the law of existence did not exist, how could the law of birth be obtained?
Therefore, the law of existence, as previously explained, causes the various destinies to continue to give rise to each other without interruption.
Ä€nanda!

You should know that this existence is a false dharma and not ultimate. This accumulation, this cause, this condition gives rise to the arising of the dharma of birth. Because of this, the dharma of birth is also not ultimate.
Furthermore, what is the condition for the dharma of existence?
Namely, the dharma of grasping is the condition.
Because of the dharma of grasping, the dharma of existence arises;
if the dharma of grasping did not exist, how could the dharma of existence be obtained?
Ä€nanda!

You should know that this dharma of grasping is a false dharma and not ultimate. This accumulation, this cause, this condition gives rise to the arising of the dharma of existence. Because of this, the dharma of existence is also not ultimate.
Furthermore, what is the condition for the dharma of grasping?
Namely, the dharma of craving is the condition.
Because of the existence of craving, the dharma of grasping arises;
if the dharma of craving did not exist, how could the dharma of grasping exist?
Ä€nanda!

It should be known that craving gives rise to desire, desire gives rise to acquisition, due to acquisition the mind is uncertain, due to uncertainty there is no contentment, due to the mind being discontent there is joy and greed, due to greed there is the arising of the view of self, once the view of self arises there is grasping, grasping gives rise to a distracted mind, due to distraction there is false speech, disputes, and fighting with weapons, and due to this cause one then creates unwholesome karma.
Such karmas all arise due to distraction;
if there were no distraction, karmas would not arise.
What is the condition for this distracted dharma?
Namely, grasping is the condition.
Due to grasping, the mind becomes distracted;
if grasping did not exist, how could distraction occur?
What is the condition for this grasping dharma?
Namely, the view of self is the condition for grasping to arise;
If the view of self did not exist, there would be no grasping and attachment.
What is the condition for this view of self?
It is said that the condition for the view of self to arise is joy and craving.
If joy and craving did not exist, there would be no view of self.
What is the condition for this joy and craving?
It is said that the condition is the lack of contentment within the mind.
Because of lack of contentment, there is joy and craving;
if the mind were content, joy and craving would not arise.
What is the condition for this lack of contentment within the mind?
It is said that the condition is indecision.
Because of indecision, there is lack of contentment;
if the mind were decisive, contentment would arise.
What is the condition for this indecision?
It is said that the condition is grasping.
Because of grasping, there is indecision;
if there were no grasping, the mind would be decisive.
What is the condition for this grasping?
It is said that the condition is seeking.
Because of seeking, there is grasping;
If there is no craving, there will be no grasping.
In this way, all these phenomena arise from the mutual conditions of craving and grasping.
You should know that there are two kinds of craving: craving for desire and craving for existence. These two dharmas give rise to faults.
Ä€nanda!

You should know that this dharma of craving is a false dharma and not ultimate. This accumulation, this cause, this arising, this condition gives rise to the dharma of grasping, and because of this, the dharma of grasping is also not ultimate.
Furthermore, what is the condition for the dharma of craving?
It is the conditioned by the dharma of feeling.
Because of the condition of feeling, the dharma of craving arises;
if the dharma of feeling did not exist, how could the dharma of craving exist?
Ä€nanda!

You should know that this dharma of feeling is a false dharma and not ultimate. This accumulation, this cause, this arising, this condition gives rise to the dharma of craving, and because of this, the dharma of craving is also not ultimate.
Furthermore, what is the condition for the dharma of feeling?
Namely, the condition of contact.
Because of the condition of contact, there is the arising of the dharma of feeling;
If the dharma of contact did not exist, how could the dharma of feeling exist?

Thus, due to the condition of eye contact, various feelings arise internally, namely, the feelings of pleasure, suffering, and neither pleasure nor suffering. In the same way, due to the condition of ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind contact, various feelings arise internally.
These various feelings are all due to the condition of the dharma of contact.
Ä€nanda!

One should know that this dharma of contact is a false and deceptive dharma, not ultimate. This accumulation, this cause, this arising, this condition gives rise to the dharma of feeling. Therefore, the dharma of feeling is also not ultimate.
Furthermore, what is the condition for the dharma of contact?
Namely, the condition of the six sense bases.
Because of the condition of the six sense bases, there is the dharma of contact;
If the six sense bases did not exist, how could the dharma of contact exist?
Ä€nanda!

You should know that these six sense bases are false and not ultimate. This accumulation, this cause, this condition gives rise to the dharma of contact. Therefore, the dharma of contact is also not ultimate.
Furthermore, what is the condition for the six sense bases?
Namely, name-and-form is the condition.
Because of name-and-form, the six sense bases arise;
if name-and-form did not exist, how could the six sense bases exist?

This name-and-form refers to the dharmas of form and the dharmas of mind, because they accumulate. This name-and-form and that dharma of consciousness mutually serve as conditions and combine to arise. This is called name-and-form.
Ä€nanda!

You should know that the dharma of name-and-form is a false dharma and not ultimate. This accumulation, this cause, this condition gives rise to the six sense bases. Therefore, the six sense bases are also not ultimate.
Furthermore, what is the condition for this dharma of name-and-form?
Namely, the dharma of consciousness is the condition.
Because of the dharma of consciousness, there is name-and-form;
If consciousness does not exist, how can name-and-form exist?

This consciousness, at the very beginning of conception, resides in the mother's womb, dependent on the kalala. When consciousness is complete, there is no increase or decrease. Because of the cause of consciousness, the aggregates arise. In this way, name-and-form is complete and perfect. One should know that this consciousness and that name-and-form arise in dependence on each other.

Furthermore, one should know that this consciousness is the condition for name-and-form. Therefore, consciousness is the condition for name-and-form, and name-and-form is the condition for consciousness.
Because of this, the fruit of suffering arises. When the fruit of suffering arises, then old age and death continue to revolve.
Because of this accumulation, because of this cause, because of this arising, because of this condition, therefore the fruit of suffering is a false dharma and not ultimate.

In this way, the conditions are: consciousness conditions name-and-form, name-and-form conditions the six sense bases, the six sense bases condition contact, contact conditions feeling, and in this way one attains the arising of the great mass of suffering.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

You should now know that all language and the path of language, neither language nor the path of language, what is produced and the path of what is produced, these two kinds are all not apart from name and form.
Ä€nanda!
If one understands in this way, one abides in the view of equality, which is called penetrating the principle of dependent origination.
This principle of dependent origination is the fundamental Dharma of all Buddhas, the eye of all Buddhas, and it is where all Buddhas return to.
At that time, the Venerable Ä€nanda praised, saying:
Excellent, World-Honored One!
You have well explained this Dharma, bringing benefit and joy to me and all the bhiká¹£us.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Ä€nanda:
I will now explain the Dharma of non-acceptance for you. You should listen attentively and accept it well, contemplating it with a good mind.
Ä€nanda!
You should know that apart from the notion of self, there is no Dharma of non-acceptance.
Why is it so?
If there is a self, then there will be the arising of the dharma of grasping.
But if one realizes that the self and dharmas are empty, how can there be a grasper?
Ä€nanda!
When both the self and the dharma of grasping have ceased, then there is nothing, abiding in the view of equality.
Ä€nanda!
The dharma of grasping has three kinds, namely, the experience of pleasure, the experience of suffering, and the experience that is neither pleasurable nor suffering.

As for the experience of pleasure, it refers to the experiencer and the dharma that is experienced. If one is able to realize that these two are dharmas that perish, then there is no experience of pleasure, and therefore no dharma that is experienced.
Why is this?
One should know that the experience of pleasure is a dharma that is impermanent. When the experience of pleasure ceases, then one is free from the notion of self;
since the notion of self is absent, what is there to be experienced?

Furthermore, as for the experience of suffering, it refers to the experiencer and the dharma that is experienced. If one is able to realize that these two are dharmas that perish, then there is no experience of suffering, and therefore no dharma that is experienced.
Why is this?
One should know that painful feeling is impermanent, and when painful feeling ceases, it is also free from the notion of self;
Since there is no notion of self, how can there be a feeler?
Furthermore, neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is also like this.

That is to say, the feeler and the feeling have two aspects. If one can understand that these two are perishable, then one will be equal towards painful, pleasant, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings, and will have nothing to feel.
Why is this?

Because these three feelings are all impermanent and ultimately unreal. When the feelings cease, they are also free from the notion of self. Since there is no notion of self, how can there be a feeler?
Ä€nanda!
What do you think?
One should know that all feelings arise from the mind. Since the mind is unmoving, internally there is no feeler. Since dharmas are unreal, externally there is nothing to be felt.
Therefore, Ä€nanda!
Understanding this, one abides in the view of equality. Abiding in this view is to understand the Dharma of non-feeling.
This Dharma of non-reception is the fundamental Dharma of all Buddhas, the eye of all Buddhas, the place where all Buddhas go.
At that time, Ä€nanda further praised and said:
Excellent, World-Honored One!
Well-spoken is this Dharma!
Having heard it, we believe, understand, and uphold it.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Ä€nanda:
I will now explain the Dharma of no-self for you. Listen carefully, receive it well, and contemplate it with a good mind.
Ä€nanda!

Understanding that feelings have no existence is the same as abandoning the view of self. Having abandoned the view of self, one abides in the view of equality. Abiding in this view, one is equal in appearance. Due to equality, one does not give rise to anything in the world. Having understood non-arising, one attains the end of birth, the establishment of the holy life, the completion of what was to be done, and does not receive another existence.
Ä€nanda!

One should know that the view of self does not arise, and abides in the view of equality. In this way, one attains the mind's liberation, without knowledge, without views, and without attainment. Free from all conceptualization, one fully understands attainment, non-attainment, neither attainment nor non-attainment.

Understanding in this way, one is without knowledge and without views regarding language and the path of language, non-language and the path of non-language, what is produced and the path of what is produced.
Having understood in this way, one is free from the view of self and abides in the view of equality. Knowing it as it really is, this is called understanding the Dharma of no-self.
This is the fundamental Dharma of all Buddhas, the eye of all Buddhas, the place where all Buddhas return.
At that time, Ä€nanda heard what the Buddha said and further praised, saying:
Excellent, World-Honored One!
Well-expounded is this Dharma!
Having heard it, we believe, understand, and uphold it.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Ä€nanda:
I will now further proclaim it for you. You should listen attentively and accept it well, with proper attention, remembering and contemplating it.
Ä€nanda!

You should know that there is no form that can be grasped. Free from all grasping at self, understand it as it truly is. Having understood it, contemplate this body as broken and unreal, not something to be delighted in.

Contemplating in this way, free from all forms, do not give rise to grasping at self. When the notion of self is extinguished, then understand this body as broken and unreal. In this way, one abides in the view of equality.
One who abides in this view immediately understands the emptiness of all the aggregates. Since the aggregates are empty, where can there be a view of self or form?
Furthermore, Ä€nanda!
You should know that there are seven abodes of consciousness and two non-abodes of consciousness.
The seven abodes of consciousness are:
Namely, if there are sentient beings with form, with various bodies and various perceptions, this is the first abode of consciousness.
If there are sentient beings with form, with various bodies and a single perception, namely the gods of the first meditation heaven, this is the second abode of consciousness.
If there are sentient beings with form, with a single body and various perceptions, namely the gods of the second meditation heaven, this is the third abode of consciousness.

If there are sentient beings with form, with a single body and a single perception, namely the gods of the third meditation heaven, this is the fourth abode of consciousness.ğŸ”½If there are formless sentient beings, in all those places free from all perceptions of form, with a single vast space, namely the gods of the sphere of infinite space, this is the fifth abode of consciousness.

If there are formless sentient beings, in all those places free from perceptions of space, with a single vast consciousness, namely the gods of the sphere of infinite consciousness, this is the sixth abode of consciousness.

If there is no form and no sentient beings, then in all those places free from the infinity of consciousness, there is absolutely nothing, namely the heaven of the sphere of nothingness. This is the seventh abode of consciousness.
Ä€nanda!
The two kinds of abodes of consciousness that are not:
Namely, if there is form and sentient beings, then the heaven of non-perception. This is the first abode of consciousness that is not.

If there is no form and no sentient beings, then in all those places free from the sphere of nothingness, neither perception nor non-perception, then the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception. This is the second abode of consciousness that is not.
The Buddha said to Ä€nanda:
There are sentient beings with form who have various bodies and various perceptions. This is the first abode of consciousness.
You bhiká¹£us!
You should understand this as it truly is. Whether walking, sitting, or speaking, you should always praise and delight in these Dharma gates, and extensively distinguish and explain them to others.

In the same way, up to the seventh consciousness, and the two non-consciousness abodes, the Dharma gates are also like this. Whether walking, standing, sitting, or speaking, always praise the Buddhas' teachings and give rise to pure faith, understanding them as they truly are.
If one understands, one will attain the fruit of an arhat liberated by wisdom.
Furthermore, Ä€nanda!
One should know the eight liberations:
Namely, internally having form, observing external forms, is the first liberation.
Internally formless, observing external forms, is the second liberation.
Bodily realization of pure liberation is the third liberation.
Having attained purity, already free from all form-related thoughts, observing a single boundless space, this observation being accomplished, is the fourth liberation of the sphere of infinite space.

If one transcends the sphere of infinite space and contemplates that consciousness is also boundless, once this contemplation is accomplished, this is the fifth liberation of the sphere of infinite consciousness.

If one transcends the sphere of infinite consciousness and contemplates that everything is utterly nonexistent, once this contemplation is accomplished, this is the sixth liberation of the sphere of nothingness.

If one transcends the sphere of nothingness and contemplates the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, once this contemplation is accomplished, this is the seventh liberation of the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.

If one transcends the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception and extinguishes perception and feeling, abiding in samÄdhi, having personally realized it, this is the eighth liberation of the cessation of perception and feeling. These are called the eight liberations.
The Buddha said to Ä€nanda:
You should know that the seven abodes of consciousness and two non-abodes of consciousness that I have previously explained, as well as the eight liberations, you and all the bhiká¹£us!
As I have explained, you should always rejoice and praise it, and further practice it in accordance with the principles.
If one fully penetrates these Dharma gates, one attains the fruit of arhatship with the two kinds of liberation.
At that time, after the World-Honored One had spoken this sÅ«tra, Venerable Ä€nanda and the bhiká¹£us all greatly rejoiced, believed and received it in faith, and practiced it.
